Award.AwardTitle: The Future of Center-Based, Multidisciplinary Engineering Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project between the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) and the National Research Council (NRC) aims to study the future of NSF's center-based, multidisciplinary engineering research. NSF's multidisciplinary, center-based, engineering research programs address a variety of key research, education, and innovation needs of the United States. Given the changing global context for engineering research, education and innovation, it is important to consider new guiding principles for constructing a new vision of such centers for the benefit of the nation. In addressing this goal, the proposed study will consider a variety of questions, including: 1) What models might most effectively enable breakthrough engineering research and discoveries that require center-scale investment considering the convergence of physical science, engineering and life science? 2) What educational models of center-based engineering research programs are best suited to creating a more diverse, internationally aware, and flexible engineering talent pool that is capable of addressing complex, real-world problems?; 3) What academic-industry partnership models might most effectively promote advances in use-inspired basic and translational research, accelerate technology commercialization, and strengthen the broader innovation ecosystem?; and 4) What metrics can be used to define successes and risks of such center programs?

This study will inform NSF and other stakeholders about future directions of multidisciplinary, center-based, engineering research. The results will potentially influence decision making by several federal agencies, state economic development offices, research universities, R&D intensive industry, and non-profit foundations interested in more effective and impactful investment in and management of large-scale, multidisciplinary engineering research. The study will be managed by a committee of experts, appointed by the presidents of the NAE and the National Academy of Sciences. The committee will conduct extensive data gathering and host a public symposium to help it articulate a new vision for NSF's multidisciplinary, center-based, engineering research over the next 10-20 years. The study will identify needs and gaps of current approaches, and provide guiding principles and possible strategies for implementing the new vision. The committee's conclusions will be published in a peer-reviewed report.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In July 2015, the National Science Foundation (NSF) asked the National Academies to conduct a study to articulate a new vision for the future of center-based engineering research—particularly for its Engineering Research Center (ERC) program, which at that time had been in operation for 30 years. In a report released in May, 2017, the Academies recommended that future ERCs should adopt two principles: 1) shifting the research emphasis to larger, grand-challenge-like problems instead of narrower technological opportunities; and 2) incorporating value-creation best practices such as those employed by the most innovative U.S. corporations and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. Addressing grand-challenge-like problems will ensure that the ERCs will remain exciting places to work, attract and train a diverse engineering workforce, and produce results of greatest value for society. Adopting value-creation best practices will help to avoid the “valley of death” between the point where the Center’s research leaves off and the point where the private sector can implement or commercialize the results for the benefit of society.

The study produced two products: 1) proceedings and videos of presentations given at a Symposium titled “A Vision for the Future of Multidisciplinary Engineering Research,” held on April 6, 2016 at the National Academies to solicit ideas from 14 presenters and approximately 100 attendees from government, universities, and industry, available at http://www.nae.edu/Projects/147474/147561/147730.aspx; and 2) the final report, “A New Vision for Center-Based Engineering Research,” available at https://www.nap.edu/catalog/24767/a-new-vision-for-center-based-engineering-research.

The Academies’ study has implications not only for NSF’s ERC program, but for center-based research generally. It was disseminated widely to Symposium attendees, as well as in presentations to the NSF Engineering Division staff, directors of the NSF Science and Technology Centers (STCs), and directors of the Engineering Research Centers. NSF responded by forming an internal cross-division working group to explore how the report’s recommendations can be implemented. One idea under consideration is how the STCs and ERCs can be more closely coordinated in the future.
